resources.string: Specialist beer tavern stocking more than 30 real ales, an imported beer selection and bar snacks.
Popular for real ales, whisky selection and pub grub, with conservatory area and stripped floors.
Lively riverside local serving pub food and real ales, with a beer garden and live music nights.

Now a privately owned pub which was reopened in March 2012 after being refurbished from January 2012. The pub has a selection of up to 16 Real Ales, (8 on hand pull and 8 on gravity) 6 to 8+ Real Ciders on at one time (more in summer) and many Lagers, Wines and Spirits.
Chain nightclub with high-tech sound and lights and a regular lineup of themed dance music events.

Bar in the center of Ipswich. Serving food Monday - Saturday, 12pm-3pm. Open till late Friday and Saturday till 3am with a live DJ from 9pm. Large drink choice and great food menu. Monthly quiz on the last Thursday of the month.
Visit the Briarbank Bar and Brewery and enjoy hand-crafted quality beers produced in our very own microbrewery, situated on the ground floor.
The New Wolsey Theatre is a Suffolk producing theatre, located in the Westgate area of Ipswich. It is a midsized regional theatre, having a seating capacity of 400.

Regent Theatre is a theatre and concert venue located at St Helens Street in Ipswich, Suffolk, England. The auditorium was recently refurbished and now holds 1,551 people, having lost around 150 seats. It is East Anglias largest theatre.
Theatre named after Sir John Mills

In the centre of Ipswich, in an area near to the Ipswich Corn Exchange known as the Giles Circus is where you will find Grandma. The statue Grandma that depicts the life and works of Carl Giles, that is. Carl Giles lived and worked in Ipswich, spending many of his working years employed by the Express Group Newspapers as a cartoonist and illustrator. Grandma, to anyone who is familiar with the work of Giles, is instantly recognisable and arguably the most famous of the characters Giles created. Grandma has pride of place in Giles Circus, and is carefully positioned so that she is looking up at the office window where Giles used to work - above what is now a coffee shop.

Bronze statue of Cardinal Thomas Wolsey sitting on a chair decorated with gothic arches and stretching his right hand, inviting the spectator to share the book held up in his left. His cardinals robes are spread out uncomfortably in front of him, while his hat hangs over the back of the chair and a cat peers round one of its legs.
The major of Majorâ€™s Corner may only be sitting from his vantage point at the top of the council toilet block swatting flies but he has become a local landmark of his own.

This is a statue dedicated to a Russian Prince who played Rugby Union for England after escaping the russian revolution, he then joined the RAF in world war 2 but died in an aeroplane crash near ipswich and is now buried in Ipswich cemetery.

Christchurch Park is a 70-acre area of rolling lawns, wooded areas, and delicately created arboreta in central Ipswich, Suffolk, England. It contains Christchurch Mansion which holds a public museum and art gallery.
This historic park features trees, ponds, a visitor centre, a maze, an open-air theatre and more.
Grassy expanse with football pitches and a playground, sometimes used for large public events.
